CMBR is continuously generated by stars and other radiologically active sources,
and contrary to popular belief not a remnant of the Big Bang.

Basically start you Universe at t=0, and go Big Bang.
Now if that event lasted in it's full radiance for a million years,
the signal length through distance would be at best 1 million light years.
It lasted 1 million years and travelled 1 million light years.

Now if you consider that matter can't travel beyond the speed of light,
the matter would have travelled much less than 1 million light years.

Since the origin of the Universe estimated to be 15 billion years ago, in order
for us to receive a signal remnant, we would have to be moving at roughly 0.999999 c,
and I think we'd notice that, in order to still receive part of that event,
otherwise the signal would have passed by in it's entirety well before today.

Radiological celestial object like the Sun, which continuously fissions and fuses,
have as byproduct a radiosignal, which then happens for all stars and other
celestial objects as long as they are still radiologically active.
These signals may have originated from sources which have since 15 billion years
moved far away from the point of emission, and so if you look through a telescope
you'd find no star there.

"Firstly, let me just say that I loved this talk, I appreciated the detail that went into explaining the concept of the CMBR. But then,  it is incredible to think that the Universe is filled with unimaginably huge clouds of hydrogen. It is even more incredible to imagine that those massive, massive clouds of hydrogen are absolutely quiescent, in terms of signal activity, when just picking up a pencil displaces trillions upon trillions of electrons.  Venturing further along this path is the strange coincidence that the CMBR almost exactly matches up with the hydrogen emission spectrum. The CMBR was never the faint relic radiation that is described, in fact it often set up a howl on old radio sets, it was a brawny, strong signal that was incredibly hard to get rid of. Today, radio reception is so sophisticated that the CMBR is hardly ever heard in any of the communication devices that we use. So there are two main questions arising from the concept put forward in the video. The first is why does the CMBR radiation so strangely mimic the hydrogen emission spectra?  The second question that comes to mind when watching this video is this;  when matter is made up of 99.999999999999%  of empty space and believe me that percentage is important when calculating the mass in the Universe and when every act from walking to being stopped from walking through walls is governed by electromagnetic interactions, how is it possible to ignore emissions that these hydrogen clouds might (must!) be emitting?  The CMBR is not relic radiation from the Big Bang. The CMBR is very much an indication of the present distribution of matter in the Universe. When considering this theory remember that previously empty places in the sky were found to be packed with galaxies."

P₁ V₁ . . P₂ V₂
-------- = ----------
T₁ . . . . .T₂
Your dry shampoo can got colder because of the equation, shown above. Both V₁ and V₂ are the same value (note that 'V' stands for volume.) However, P₂ is necessarily smaller in magnitude than P₁ (note that 'P' stands for pressure), so, in order to maintain the equality expressed by the equation, T₂ has to compensate by being smaller (in magnitude) than T₁ . Since 'T' stands for temperature, this means that the final temperature inside the can (i.e. T₂) is colder than the initial temperature inside the can, T₁ .

Paris Herouni built a radio antenna that was hemispherical in shape. Built this way, he was able to eliminate most of the noise from Earth. The result was that his antenna had less base noise than the supposed CMB (at 2.7 degrees Kelvin). Based on this, Herouni concluded there was no CMB and therefore no Big Bang, . I wish you would be a bit more nuanced about dark energy and dark matter, though, since we have no direct evidence of what they are and because although they are well accepted, our lack of understanding may mean we'll be surprised. Dark matter is a short hand for it looks like there isn't enough energy to keep things together according to our understanding of physics and we can map exactly where invisible matter would have to be to make it make sense. Dark energy is shorthand for our understanding of physics doesn't explain why the expansion of the universe is accelerating so we postulate an unknown form of energy which is causing the acceleration. For both of those there are several alternative explanations and so far we don't have experiments that will allow us to pick, so intellectual integrity would call for a more nuanced approach in science education rather than just talking about dark energy and dark matter as facts, as things, as known. It is more of a pain to talk about it carefully, of course, but it's more honest, right?

I'm glad you covered the polarization from our velocity. It's filtered out of nearly every CMB image you find and is rarely mentioned. It's the closest you can come to a lower bound on an absolute velocity but really it's a 4-vector normal to the 3-dimensional surface of 'now' assuming there were no significant large scale flows prior to the last scattering.

It's easier to drop two dimensions and think about the normal to a circle drawn on the complex plane where the radius is time, t=||τ+ix/c||=√(τ²-i²x²/c²) with i²=-1 and c is the speed of light in the same units as x/t. Gravity makes it a slightly lumpy circle so the normal won't be perfectly radial near massive objects. Note that this means anything stationary with respect to its view of the CMB that is ±90° or more from your position on the circle necessarily appears to be moving away from you faster than the speed of light. That's just Hubble flow, though, not "real" velocity. Relatedly, the circle necessarily expands as t increases so position of a stationary object would be better defined as an angle rather than a distance. Alternatively, you can use comoving distances (popular with cosmologists) which also factor out the expansion. I find it easier to use an angle as you just multiply by the time to get the distance at that time. This is a very simplified model compared to FLRW and the various inflation models but it matches Hubble reasonably well and gives a possible geometric explanation for the cosmological constant as an alternative to dark energy. Also, if you treat your 4-velocity vector as your arrow of time and use that in place of 1-dimensional time and 3-velocity to describe a particle, then everything beyond ±90° is also indistinguishable from antimatter—something that would be true no matter where you are in the universe with no need to explain separation of the two or the supposed matter-antimatter imbalance as it's an expected continuous velocity gradient not a sign flip.
